back: Alluvial plain area alongside and between the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers.
Challenging due to little rainfall, untimely river floods, and unpredictable river courses. Crops included barley, date palms, vegetables, reeds, and fish.
Earliest people of Mesopotamia, present by 5000 BCE. Supplanted by Semitic-speaking peoples around 2000 BCE, preserving many Sumerian cultural elements.

Mesopotamian society of villages and cities forming city-states. Interdependence: villages supplied food, and cities provided protection, markets, and goods. City-states engaged in both conflict and cooperation.

Secular leadership emerged with 'big men' (lugal) in the third millennium BCE. Temples and palaces were centers of power. Eventually led to larger territorial states like the Akkadian state and the Third Dynasty of Ur.
Established the 'Old Babylonian' state. Known for the Law Code associated with his name, offering insights into Old Babylonian law, punishments, and society.
Stratified society with kings and priests controlling wealth. Three classes: (1) free landowning class, (2) dependent farmers and artisans, (3) slaves (mostly prisoners of war).
An amalgam of Sumerian and Semitic beliefs. Anthropomorphic deities with each city having its own tutelary gods. Temples, priests, and the ziggurat were central to religious practices.

Advanced in writing (cuneiform), irrigation, transportation, bronze metallurgy, engineering, and pottery. Military technology included the horse-drawn chariot and bow and arrow. Significant contributions to mathematics and astronomy.
Defined by the Nile River, arable land on its banks, and the Nile delta. Divided into Upper and Lower Egypt. Nile floods provided fertile soil for agriculture.

Pharaohs, considered gods on earth, ensured people's welfare and prosperity. Death of a pharaoh marked the beginning of a journey back to the land of the gods. Elaborate tombs, including pyramids, emphasized the importance of the afterlife.
Centralized administration governed through a system of bureaucracies. Two writing systems: hieroglyphics and a cursive script. Tensions between central and local government were common.
Direct and indirect trade with regions like the Levant, Nubia, and possibly Punt. Exports included papyrus, grain, and gold. Imports comprised incense, cedar, and African ivory.
Pharaohs and high-ranking officials, lower-level officials, local leaders, priests, professionals, artisans, well-off farmers, and peasants. Majority of the population consisted of peasants.

Cyclical view of nature with gods like Re and Osiris symbolizing renewal and life after death. Pharaohs served as chief priests. Egyptians invested heavily in constructing temples and believed in magic and an afterlife.
Advanced in various fields such as chemistry and anatomy (mummification process), mathematics, astronomy, calendar making, irrigation, engineering, and transportation technology.

Flourished from 2600 to 1900 BCE. Limited knowledge due to undeciphered writing. Major urban centers: Harappa and Mohenjo-daro. Uniform city planning and advanced technologies, including bronze metallurgy.
Previously attributed to invasion, now believed to result from natural disasters and ecological changes. Factors include the drying up of the Hakra River, salinization, and erosion.
